items.title: Trump pardons convicted Binance founder Zhao, White House says
Trump pardons founder of Binance, world’s largest crypto exchange
items.standfirst: Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to stop money laundering in 2023 and was sentenced to four monthsDonald Trump issued a pardon for the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange on Thursday.“President Trump exercised his constitutional authority by issuing a pardon for Mr Zhao, who was prosecuted by the Biden Administration in their war on cryptocurrency,” a White House statement said. “The war on crypto is over.” Continue reading...
items.content: Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to stop money laundering in 2023 and was sentenced to four monthsDonald Trump issued a pardon for the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange on Thursday.“President Trump exercised his constitutional authority by issuing a pardon for Mr Zhao, who was prosecuted by the Biden Administration in their war on cryptocurrency,” a White House statement said. “The war on crypto is over.” Continue reading...

items.title: Putin says Russian response to Ukrainian use of Tomahawks would be 'overwhelming'
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Thursday that if Ukraine gets and uses US Tomahawk missiles the response from Russia would be "very serious, if not overwhelming". At the same time the Russian president pledged to continue dialogue with the US, despite US counterpart Donald Trump shelving a summit between the two leaders.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Thursday that if Ukraine gets and uses US Tomahawk missiles the response from Russia would be "very serious, if not overwhelming". At the same time the Russian president pledged to continue dialogue with the US, despite US counterpart Donald Trump shelving a summit between the two leaders.

items.title: U.S. sanctions Russia's two largest oil companies
items.standfirst: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a statement.
items.content: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a statement.

ai_summary: Donald Trump pardoned Changpeng Zhao, founder of Binance, after his money laundering conviction.
Zhao pleaded guilty to failing to prevent money laundering and was sentenced to four months.
The White House stated the Biden administration "overly prosecuted" Zhao and Binance.
Karoline Leavitt, White House press secretary, said the "war on crypto is over".
Reuters reported that Trump may meet with Vladimir Putin.

Vance called the vote "stupid" and said Trump would not back annexation.
Secretary of State Rubio warned of the impact on Gaza peace plans.
Vance rejected any Israeli annexation of the occupied West Bank during his trip.
The US officials' remarks came as the Trump administration seeks a Gaza ceasefire.

items.content: Charges are related to insider sports betting and another that rigged poker games nationwide linked with NBA and Mafia.

items.title: NBA's Rozier and Billups among dozens of arrests in illegal betting probe
items.standfirst: Among those taken into custody in the betting investigation today are Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier of the Miami Heat and former NBA player Damon Jones.
items.content: Among those taken into custody in the betting investigation today are Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier of the Miami Heat and former NBA player Damon Jones.

items.title: NBA reacts to arrests of Chauncey Billups, Terry Rozier on illegal gambling charges
items.standfirst: Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups and Miami Heat player Terry Rozier were among dozens of people charged in connection to two investigations into an alleged widespread sports betting scheme and organized crime ring, the FBI and federal prosecutors announced Thursday. CBS News justice correspondent Scott MacFarlane has more.
items.content: Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups and Miami Heat player Terry Rozier were among dozens of people charged in connection to two investigations into an alleged widespread sports betting scheme and organized crime ring, the FBI and federal prosecutors announced Thursday. CBS News justice correspondent Scott MacFarlane has more.

items.title: Who are the NBA coaches and player arrested for illegal sports betting and rigged poker games
items.standfirst: Three people were arrested Thursday in connection with a federal investigation into illegal sports betting and rigged poker games.
items.content: Three people were arrested Thursday in connection with a federal investigation into illegal sports betting and rigged poker games.

items.title: NBA player and head coach among 30 arrested in illegal US gambling investigation
items.standfirst: FBI says years-long operation that led to arrest of Heat’s Terry Rozier and Trail Blazers’ Chauncey Billups also connected to mafia families The NBA, one of the world’s most prominent sports leagues, found itself associated with illegal gambling again on Thursday after two prominent stars were arrested in a sweeping federal investigation. Chauncey Billups, a Hall of Fame player who is now coach of the Portland Trail Blazers, was arrested in connection with a poker operation linked to the mafia, while Miami Heat star Terry Rozier is accused of taking part in a scheme to manipulate games.“Today, we are here in New York to announce a historic arrest across a wide sweeping criminal enterprise,” the FBI director, Kash Patel, said at a news conference on Thursday unveiling the charges. “This is an illegal gambling operation and sports rigging operation that spanned the course of years.” Continue reading...
items.content: FBI says years-long operation that led to arrest of Heat’s Terry Rozier and Trail Blazers’ Chauncey Billups also connected to mafia families The NBA, one of the world’s most prominent sports leagues, found itself associated with illegal gambling again on Thursday after two prominent stars were arrested in a sweeping federal investigation. Chauncey Billups, a Hall of Fame player who is now coach of the Portland Trail Blazers, was arrested in connection with a poker operation linked to the mafia, while Miami Heat star Terry Rozier is accused of taking part in a scheme to manipulate games.“Today, we are here in New York to announce a historic arrest across a wide sweeping criminal enterprise,” the FBI director, Kash Patel, said at a news conference on Thursday unveiling the charges. “This is an illegal gambling operation and sports rigging operation that spanned the course of years.” Continue reading...

According to the 10-year NBA veteran's lawyer, he had been aware of the investigation for over a year and cooperated with officials during that…

According to the 10-year NBA veteran's lawyer, he had been aware of the investigation for over a year and cooperated with officials during that…

items.title: NBA’s Terry Rozier, Chauncey Billups arrested in sports bet probe
items.standfirst: Chauncey Billups's arrest was linked to an illegal poker operation tied to the Mafia, according to US media reports.
items.content: Chauncey Billups's arrest was linked to an illegal poker operation tied to the Mafia, according to US media reports.

items.title: NBA coach Chauncey Billups, player Terry Rozier arrested in FBI gambling probe
items.standfirst: Prosecutors say Rozier and others passed confidential intel to organized crime groups to help wager on NBA games. Billups allegedly participated in a separate scheme involving underground poker games.
items.content: Prosecutors say Rozier and others passed confidential intel to organized crime groups to help wager on NBA games. Billups allegedly participated in a separate scheme involving underground poker games.(Image credit: Carmen Mandato)

ai_summary: Over 30 arrests were made in an FBI crackdown on illegal gambling related to the NBA.
Chauncey Billups, coach of the Portland Trail Blazers, was among those arrested.
Terry Rozier of the Miami Heat was also arrested in the investigation.
The investigation involved sports betting and rigged poker games.
The FBI stated the operation was connected to organized crime families.

clusters.title: Senate fails to advance GOP bill to pay essential workers during shutdown
clusters.neutral_headline: Senate Fails to Pass Bill to Pay Federal Workers

items.title: Senate fails to advance GOP bill to pay essential workers during shutdown
items.standfirst: The government shutdown stretched into Day 23 on Thursday as the Senate failed to advance a measure to pay some federal workers. Follow live updates here.
items.content: The government shutdown stretched into Day 23 on Thursday as the Senate failed to advance a measure to pay some federal workers. Follow live updates here.

items.title: US Senate fails to pass bill to pay federal essential workers and troops through shutdown
items.standfirst: Shutdown Fairness Act, introduced by Ron Johnson, a Republican senator of Wisconsin, failed in a 54-45 voteUS politics live – latest updatesThe Senate failed on Thursday to pass legislation that would keep federal workers deemed essential and troops paid throughout the ongoing government shutdown – now in its 23rd day.With a 54-45 vote, the upper chamber failed to meet the 60-vote threshold needed to advance the Shutdown Fairness Act, introduced by Ron Johnson, a Republican senator of Wisconsin. Continue reading...
items.content: Shutdown Fairness Act, introduced by Ron Johnson, a Republican senator of Wisconsin, failed in a 54-45 voteUS politics live – latest updatesThe Senate failed on Thursday to pass legislation that would keep federal workers deemed essential and troops paid throughout the ongoing government shutdown – now in its 23rd day.With a 54-45 vote, the upper chamber failed to meet the 60-vote threshold needed to advance the Shutdown Fairness Act, introduced by Ron Johnson, a Republican senator of Wisconsin. Continue reading...

items.title: Effort to pay at least some federal workers fails in Senate
items.standfirst: The Senate failed to advance two partisan bills that would have paid some federal workers during the shutdown. Democrats and Republicans remain deadlocked as the shutdown drags on.
items.content: The Senate failed to advance two partisan bills that would have paid some federal workers during the shutdown. Democrats and Republicans remain deadlocked as the shutdown drags on.(Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

items.content: As the government shutdown stretches into a fourth week, lawmakers are no closer to ending it.

items.title: Senate rejects dueling bills to pay federal workers
items.standfirst: The Senate on Thursday rejected a pair of bills that would have paid military servicemembers, along with some or all federal workers during the shutdown. Why it matters: Republicans and Democrats wouldn't back each other's proposals, leaving the Senate still deadlocked on any solution to open the…
items.content: The Senate on Thursday rejected a pair of bills that would have paid military servicemembers, along with some or all federal workers during the shutdown. Why it matters: Republicans and Democrats wouldn't back each other's proposals, leaving the Senate still deadlocked on any solution to open the…

ai_summary: The Senate failed to pass a bill to pay essential federal workers during the shutdown.
The Shutdown Fairness Act, introduced by Ron Johnson, failed to get enough votes.
Democrats blocked a Republican measure to pay essential government employees.
Republicans blocked Democratic bills to pay a broader range of workers.
The government shutdown continued into its 23rd day.

items.title: Apple Loses UK Class Action Over Excessive App Store Charges
Apple Loses UK Class Action Over Excessive App Store Charges
items.standfirst: Apple Inc. lost a class-action in the UK after a court ruled that it abused its dominant position to charge excessive commission from app developers.
items.content: Apple Inc. lost a class-action in the UK after a court ruled that it abused its dominant position to charge excessive commission from app developers.

ai_summary: Apple lost a UK class action lawsuit regarding excessive App Store charges.
The court ruled Apple abused its dominant position with excessive commissions.
Claimants stated 36 million consumers could be entitled to damages.
Damages are estimated to be around £1.5 billion.
Apple was found to have shut out competition.

clusters.title: Americans react to White House ballroom construction after East Wing demolition
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump's Ballroom Construction Replaces White House East Wing

items.title: Americans react to White House ballroom construction after East Wing demolition
items.standfirst: Americans are reacting to news of the Trump administration tearing down parts of the East Wing to make room for a massive ballroom on White House grounds. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi reports.
items.content: Americans are reacting to news of the Trump administration tearing down parts of the East Wing to make room for a massive ballroom on White House grounds. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi reports.

items.title: How presidents have changed the White House — and how Trump's ballroom is different
items.standfirst: President Trump is demolishing the East Wing to make room for a ballroom. His administration says he's continuing a presidential legacy of White House renovations, but this is the biggest in decades.
items.content: President Trump is demolishing the East Wing to make room for a ballroom. His administration says he's continuing a presidential legacy of White House renovations, but this is the biggest in decades.(Image credit: File)

items.title: The East Wing could fully be demolished soon, as preservationists urge caution
items.standfirst: President Trump is plowing ahead with plans to build a grand ballroom where the East Wing of the White House currently stands. The plans have not gone through the committee tasked with overseeing such projects.
items.content: President Trump is plowing ahead with plans to build a grand ballroom where the East Wing of the White House currently stands. The plans have not gone through the committee tasked with overseeing such projects.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

items.title: White House East Wing Latest: New Photos Show Full Demolition
items.standfirst: The entire East Wing of the White House has been demolished as President Donald Trump moves forward with plans to build a $300 million ballroom, according to Associated Press photos released Thursday. The East Wing — long home to first ladies’ offices, state dinner planning and ceremonial events —…
items.content: The entire East Wing of the White House has been demolished as President Donald Trump moves forward with plans to build a $300 million ballroom, according to Associated Press photos released Thursday. The East Wing — long home to first ladies’ offices, state dinner planning and ceremonial events —…

items.title: Entire White House East Wing demolished as Trump moves forward with ballroom construction
items.standfirst: The East Wing has been demolished as part of the president’s plan to build what he says is a $300 million ballroom nearly twice the size of the White House itself.
items.content: The East Wing has been demolished as part of the president’s plan to build what he says is a $300 million ballroom nearly twice the size of the White House itself.

items.title: Trump’s huge ballroom to replace razed East Wing
items.standfirst: What happened President Donald Trump Wednesday acknowledged that the White House’s East Wing would be completely demolished to build his ballroom, despite his earlier pledge that the project “won’t interfere with the current building.” He also said the cavernous ballroom would cost $300 million,…
items.content: What happened President Donald Trump Wednesday acknowledged that the White House’s East Wing would be completely demolished to build his ballroom, despite his earlier pledge that the project “won’t interfere with the current building.” He also said the cavernous ballroom would cost $300 million,…

ai_summary: The East Wing of the White House has been demolished for a ballroom.
The ballroom is planned to cost $300 million.
The ballroom will be nearly twice the size of the existing White House.
The demolition has been confirmed by President Trump.
Preservationists have urged caution regarding the project.

clusters.title: Colombia urges US to halt strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats: ‘It is murder’
clusters.neutral_headline: US Strikes on Boats in South America Draw Criticism

items.title: Colombia urges US to halt strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats: ‘It is murder’
items.standfirst: Plea comes after Pete Hegseth announced two new strikes that left at least five people deadColombia has condemned US airstrikes on vessels allegedly involved in drug-smuggling off the coast of South America, urging Washington to immediately halt further attacks in the Pacific and Caribbean.The plea came after Pete Hegseth, the US secretary of defense, announced two new strikes on Wednesday, which were the first to hit the Pacific and left at least five people dead. According to US figures, at least nine attacks have now been carried out since early September, killing 37 people. A broad range of experts have said the campaign is illegal. Continue reading...
items.content: Plea comes after Pete Hegseth announced two new strikes that left at least five people deadColombia has condemned US airstrikes on vessels allegedly involved in drug-smuggling off the coast of South America, urging Washington to immediately halt further attacks in the Pacific and Caribbean.The plea came after Pete Hegseth, the US secretary of defense, announced two new strikes on Wednesday, which were the first to hit the Pacific and left at least five people dead. According to US figures, at least nine attacks have now been carried out since early September, killing 37 people. A broad range of experts have said the campaign is illegal. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump expands boat strikes to Pacific, killing 5 more
items.standfirst: What happened Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said Wednesday that the U.S. military had destroyed two more alleged drug smuggling boats in international waters, killing five people. items.title: A timeline of U.S. military strikes on boats off South America and what Congress has said
items.standfirst: In less than two months, President Donald Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth say the U.S. military has killed at least 37 people in nine strikes against drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean.
items.content: In less than two months, President Donald Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth say the U.S. military has killed at least 37 people in nine strikes against drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean.

items.title: US carries out two strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats in the Pacific
items.standfirst: The United States has conducted two military strikes on vessels alleged to be carrying illicit drugs across international waters, killing five people. For the first time the boats in question were not in the Caribbean Sea but instead in the Pacific Ocean. There have now been at least nine strikes in total, killing 37 people. Solange Mougin and Gaelle Fonseca report.
items.content: The United States has conducted two military strikes on vessels alleged to be carrying illicit drugs across international waters, killing five people. For the first time the boats in question were not in the Caribbean Sea but instead in the Pacific Ocean. There have now been at least nine strikes in total, killing 37 people. Solange Mougin and Gaelle Fonseca report.

items.title: US military kills five people in strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in Pacific
items.standfirst: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32The US military has for the first time attacked and destroyed two boats on the Pacific side of South America, as part of its controversial fight against what it says are drug-trafficking activities.The strikes – on Tuesday night and then early on Wednesday – killed five people, according to the US defence secretary, Pete Hegseth. They came on top of at least seven other strikes in the Caribbean that have killed at least 32 people and raised tensions with Colombia and Venezuela. Continue reading...
items.content: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32The US military has for the first time attacked and destroyed two boats on the Pacific side of South America, as part of its controversial fight against what it says are drug-trafficking activities.The strikes – on Tuesday night and then early on Wednesday – killed five people, according to the US defence secretary, Pete Hegseth. They came on top of at least seven other strikes in the Caribbean that have killed at least 32 people and raised tensions with Colombia and Venezuela. Continue reading...

The US military conducted two strikes in the Pacific, killing five people.
The strikes are part of a campaign against "narcoterrorists".
At least nine strikes have occurred, resulting in 37 deaths.
Experts have questioned the legality of the US military actions.

clusters.title: Soldier F case should serve as a caution for future Troubles prosecutions
clusters.neutral_headline: Soldier F Acquitted in Bloody Sunday Trial

items.title: Soldier F case should serve as a caution for future Troubles prosecutions
items.standfirst: In finding F not guilty of murder on Bloody Sunday, judge said evidence fell well short of the standard requiredIt is undisputed that members of the Parachute regiment shot dead 13 unarmed civil rights protesters in Derry on Bloody Sunday. But, more than 53 years later, it is not surprising that Soldier F, the only man put on trial for murder, was found not guilty.Though four of the Paras who entered Glenfada Park North had “lost all sense of military discipline”, according to Mr Justice Lynch, direct evidence against Soldier F fell well short of “the high standard of proof required in a criminal case”. Continue reading...
items.content: In finding F not guilty of murder on Bloody Sunday, judge said evidence fell well short of the standard requiredIt is undisputed that members of the Parachute regiment shot dead 13 unarmed civil rights protesters in Derry on Bloody Sunday. But, more than 53 years later, it is not surprising that Soldier F, the only man put on trial for murder, was found not guilty.Though four of the Paras who entered Glenfada Park North had “lost all sense of military discipline”, according to Mr Justice Lynch, direct evidence against Soldier F fell well short of “the high standard of proof required in a criminal case”. Continue reading...

items.title: Why did the judge acquit Soldier F in Bloody Sunday trial?
items.standfirst: Mr Justice Lynch said troops had "lost all sense of military discipline" but cast doubt on the level of evidence provided on who fired the shots.
items.content: Mr Justice Lynch said troops had "lost all sense of military discipline" but cast doubt on the level of evidence provided on who fired the shots.

ai_summary: Soldier F was found not guilty of murder in the Bloody Sunday trial.

The trial was related to the shooting of unarmed civil rights protesters.
The events occurred in Derry on Bloody Sunday.

He said Ukraine would use a significant part of the assets to buy weapons from its European allies. Continue reading...

He said Ukraine would use a significant part of the assets to buy weapons from its European allies. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelensky urges EU to use frozen Russian assets to arm and rebuild Ukraine
items.standfirst: President Volodymyr Zelensky said Ukraine should be allowed to use frozen Russian assets to fund domestic weapons production and purchase arms from Europe and the U.S. Speaking at a press conference in Brussels, he urged the EU to approve a major “reparations loan” backed by those assets, saying he hoped for a positive political decision soon. “Russia brought war to our land, and they must pay for it,” Zelensky said. France24 International Affairs Commentator Douglas Herbert explains what's at stake.
items.content: President Volodymyr Zelensky said Ukraine should be allowed to use frozen Russian assets to fund domestic weapons production and purchase arms from Europe and the U.S. Speaking at a press conference in Brussels, he urged the EU to approve a major “reparations loan” backed by those assets, saying he hoped for a positive political decision soon. “Russia brought war to our land, and they must pay for it,” Zelensky said. France24 International Affairs Commentator Douglas Herbert explains what's at stake.

items.title: REPLAY: Ukrainian President Zelensky addresses reporters after EU Summit
items.standfirst: During his speech at the European Parliament on Thursday, Ukrainian President Zelensky said Ukraine should be able to use Russian frozen assets for domestic weapons production. Here’s the replay of his address.
items.content: During his speech at the European Parliament on Thursday, Ukrainian President Zelensky said Ukraine should be able to use Russian frozen assets for domestic weapons production. Here’s the replay of his address.

items.title: Zelensky calls for EU decision on frozen Russia assets as soon as possible
items.standfirst: President Volodymyr Zelensky urged European allies on Thursday to supply Ukraine with long-range weapons after failing to secure a promise from US President Donald Trump to provide Kyiv with powerful Tomahawk missiles. Zelensky, who addressed European Union leaders in Brussels, also called on them to agree as soon as possible on a plan to use frozen Russian assets and said Kyiv would use a "significant part" of any funds made available to buy European-made weapons. France24 International Affairs Commentator Douglas Herbert joins us for more.
items.content: President Volodymyr Zelensky urged European allies on Thursday to supply Ukraine with long-range weapons after failing to secure a promise from US President Donald Trump to provide Kyiv with powerful Tomahawk missiles. Zelensky, who addressed European Union leaders in Brussels, also called on them to agree as soon as possible on a plan to use frozen Russian assets and said Kyiv would use a "significant part" of any funds made available to buy European-made weapons. France24 International Affairs Commentator Douglas Herbert joins us for more.

items.title: EU poised to agree on using frozen Russian assets to help Ukraine in war
items.standfirst: President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday urged European allies to provide Ukraine with long-range weapons after failing to secure a commitment from U.S. President Donald Trump to supply Tomahawk missiles. Speaking to EU leaders in Brussels, Zelensky also pressed them to swiftly approve a plan to use frozen Russian assets, saying a substantial portion of the funds would go toward purchasing European-made weapons. Here's the latest from France24 correspondent Dave Keating reporting from Brussels.
items.content: President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday urged European allies to provide Ukraine with long-range weapons after failing to secure a commitment from U.S. President Donald Trump to supply Tomahawk missiles. Speaking to EU leaders in Brussels, Zelensky also pressed them to swiftly approve a plan to use frozen Russian assets, saying a substantial portion of the funds would go toward purchasing European-made weapons. Here's the latest from France24 correspondent Dave Keating reporting from Brussels.

items.title: EU joins US in heaping more sanctions on Russia to push Putin into Ukraine peace talks
items.standfirst: The European Union on Thursday imposed new economic sanctions on Russia, following U.S. President Donald Trump’s additional measures targeting the Russian oil sector a day earlier. Russian officials and state media downplayed the impact, calling the Western actions ineffective. The latest sanctions aim to cut off the revenue and resources sustaining Moscow’s war in Ukraine and push President Vladimir Putin toward negotiations. The move marks a diplomatic win for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, who has long urged stronger international punishment for Russia’s invasion. France24 International Affairs commentator Douglas Herbert gives his insights.
items.content: The European Union on Thursday imposed new economic sanctions on Russia, following U.S. President Donald Trump’s additional measures targeting the Russian oil sector a day earlier. Russian officials and state media downplayed the impact, calling the Western actions ineffective. The latest sanctions aim to cut off the revenue and resources sustaining Moscow’s war in Ukraine and push President Vladimir Putin toward negotiations. The move marks a diplomatic win for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, who has long urged stronger international punishment for Russia’s invasion. France24 International Affairs commentator Douglas Herbert gives his insights.

ai_summary: Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged the EU to use frozen Russian assets for Ukraine's defense.
Zelenskyy wants a decision on using the assets "as soon as possible".
He called for a major "reparations loan" backed by the assets.
Putin called new US sanctions an "unfriendly act".
Zelenskyy said Russia must pay for the war.

clusters.title: Israel calls ICJ Decision 'Shameful'
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel calls ICJ Decision 'Shameful

items.title: Israel calls ICJ Decision 'Shameful'
items.standfirst: Israel is rejecting a ruling by the International Court of Justice that orders it to ease the passage of aid into Gaza. The UN aid agency has been effectively barred from operating in the enclave since January. The decision comes as humanitarian organizations scramble to scale up desperately needed aid to the territory. Meanwhile, funerals are being held for dozens of unidentified Palestinians whose remains were recently handed over by Israel.
items.content: Israel is rejecting a ruling by the International Court of Justice that orders it to ease the passage of aid into Gaza. The UN aid agency has been effectively barred from operating in the enclave since January. The decision comes as humanitarian organizations scramble to scale up desperately needed aid to the territory. Meanwhile, funerals are being held for dozens of unidentified Palestinians whose remains were recently handed over by Israel.

items.title: ICJ orders Israel to allow aid into Gaza and says restrictions breached international obligations
items.standfirst: UN’s top court also finds Israel failed to justify blocking Unrwa and other relief agenciesIsrael must allow aid into Gaza, and its restrictions on doing so over the past two years have put it in breach of its obligations, the UN’s top court has found.The stinging advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice in The Hague also found that Israel had a duty not to impede the supply of aid by UN organisations including the beleaguered UN Palestinian relief agency Unrwa, which has been in effect banned from the territory since January. Continue reading...
items.content: UN’s top court also finds Israel failed to justify blocking Unrwa and other relief agenciesIsrael must allow aid into Gaza, and its restrictions on doing so over the past two years have put it in breach of its obligations, the UN’s top court has found.The stinging advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice in The Hague also found that Israel had a duty not to impede the supply of aid by UN organisations including the beleaguered UN Palestinian relief agency Unrwa, which has been in effect banned from the territory since January. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israel rejected the ICJ ruling to ease aid into Gaza.
The ICJ ordered Israel to allow aid into Gaza.
The ICJ found Israel's restrictions breached obligations.
Israel has blocked the UN aid agency from operating.
Funerals are being held for unidentified Palestinian remains.
